#Importing the required libraries

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import plotly.graph_objects as go
import plotly.express as px
source.027c3815:
#Creating the Dataframe

df = pd.read_csv("../input/kaggle-survey-2020/kaggle_survey_2020_responses.csv", low_memory=False)

#Creating secondary DataFrames to organize questions
q = df.iloc[0, :].T
data = df.iloc[1:, :]

       'Q17_Part_7', 'Q17_Part_8', 'Q17_Part_9', 'Q17_Part_10', 'Q17_Part_11',

source.a4848e9d:
man = df.query('Q2 == "Man"')
man = man['Q1'].value_counts().sort_index().values

woman = df.query('Q2 == "Woman"')
woman = woman['Q1'].value_counts().sort_index().values * -1
woman

layout = go.Layout(yaxis=go.layout.YAxis(title='Age'),
                   xaxis=go.layout.XAxis(
                       range=[-3100, 3100],
                       tickvals=np.arange(-3000, 3001, 500),
                       ticktext=np.arange(-3000, 3001, 500)),
                   barmode='overlay',
                   bargap=0.1,
                   title={'text':'Respondents age pyramid', 'y':0.9, 'x':0.5,'xanchor': 'center', 'yanchor': 'top'},
                   font_family='Rockwell', template="simple_white")

data = [go.Bar(y=['18-21', '22-24', '25-29', '30-34', '35-39', '40-44','45-49', '50-54', '55-59', '60-69', '70+'],
               x=man,
               orientation='h',
               name='Men',
               hoverinfo='x',
               marker=dict(color='crimson')
               ),
        go.Bar(y=['18-21', '22-24', '25-29', '30-34', '35-39', '40-44','45-49', '50-54', '55-59', '60-69', '70+'],
               x=woman,
               orientation='h',
               name='Women',
               #text=-1 * women_bins.astype('int'),
               hoverinfo='text',
               marker=dict(color='teal')
               )]


go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
source.ed7e98da:
#Creating a dataframe with countries

country = df['Q3'].value_counts()
country = pd.DataFrame(country)
country = country.reset_index()

#Creating a column with only "NaN" to get the country codes.

country['Code'] = np.nan

#Renaming the DataFrame country columns to fit with the df1 

country.columns = ['Name', 'Quantity', 'Code']
country['Name'][1] = "United States"
country['Name'][6] = "United Kingdom"
country['Name'][20] = "Korea, Rep"
country['Name'][24] = "Iran"
country['Name'][44] = "Korea, Dem. Rep."

#This df1 is a dataset that I took where I already had the country acronyms

df1 = px.data.gapminder().query("year==2007")

#Creating a for to get country codes

lista = country['Name'].unique()
lista
for i in range (len(lista)):
  if country['Name'][i] in list(df1['country']):
    country['Code'][i] = df1.query(f"country == '{lista[i]}'")['iso_alpha'].to_list()[0]
    
#Renaming codes that did not work for

country['Code'][5] = 'RUS'
country['Code'][20] = 'PRK'
country['Code'][23] = 'UKR'
country['Code'][29] = 'VNM'
country['Code'][51] = 'ARE'
country['Code'][52] = 'BLR'
source.f1ec0d24:
#Global Graphic


fig = px.scatter_geo(country, locations="Code", color="Name",
                     hover_name="Name", size='Quantity',
                     projection="equirectangular", title='Distribution of people by countries', size_max=28)
fig.update_layout(title={'y':0.9, 'x':0.5,'xanchor': 'center', 'yanchor': 'top'}, font_family='Rockwell',
                  font=dict(size=16), template="simple_white")
fig.show()

                  font=dict(size=14, color="black"), xaxis_title='Formation',
                  yaxis_title='Frequency',
                  font_family='Rockwell', template="simple_white")
fig.show()

fig.show()

source.395c6d9b:
# Creating a series to gather all the responses from the form

lp_n = []
lp = []
for i in ['Q7_Part_1', 'Q7_Part_2', 'Q7_Part_3', 'Q7_Part_4', 'Q7_Part_5','Q7_Part_6', 'Q7_Part_7', 'Q7_Part_8', 'Q7_Part_9', 'Q7_Part_10','Q7_Part_11', 'Q7_Part_12', 'Q7_OTHER']:
  lp_n.append(df_ds[i].value_counts().index[0])
  lp.append(df_ds[i].value_counts().values[0])
    
li = pd.Series(lp, lp_n)

# Graph of mainly programing languages of the Data Scientist

colors = ['teal'] * 13
colors[0] = 'crimson'
colors[1] = 'crimson'
colors[2] = 'crimson'

fig = go.Figure([go.Bar(x=li.sort_values(ascending=False).index , y=li.sort_values(ascending=False).values, marker=dict(color=colors))])
fig.update_layout( title={'text':'The mainly programing languages of the Data Scientist', 'y':0.9, 'x':0.5,'xanchor': 'center', 'yanchor': 'top'}, font=dict(size=16, color="black"),
                  xaxis_title='Languages', yaxis_title='Frequency', font_family='Rockwell', template="simple_white")
fig.show()

                        values=[df_ds["Q8"].value_counts().values[0], df_ds["Q8"].value_counts().values[1] + df_ds["Q8"].value_counts().values[2]], marker=dict(colors=colors))])

source.be62dcdf: Photo by Lukas Blazek on Unsplash
source.6329dade: And here we have the most used algorithms during the analysis.
source.74246b33: Now I want you to see one thing: if you are young and looking for a career in the field of Data Science, see that most young people are still students too:
source.ab2cf649:
Our first stop is in the genre: from the chart below we can see that most Data Scientists are male. If you're female, know that there is still a lot of space to be conquered, so don't worry!

Another thing we can see is the age of these people, we have a large part of "Data Workers" in the age group between 18 and 34 years. In other words, we have people of all ages!
source.a86b2098: The work of a Data Scientist covers several areas. In this graph you will see the main activities:
source.6616f0dc: Meanwhile, older people mostly work as Data Scientists, but don't worry, if you're entering the field at that age there are still a good number of people studying. It's never late to start!
source.c8d00426: Our second stop is in the programming languages that Data Scientists use.
source.03852971:
Now you may be asking yourself, "omg what functions are these? I thought I would be a Data Scientist". So, my dear friend, in a way, they are all "Data Scientists", because they all work with data, but each one does something different. I will explain to you what each one does:

* **Data Scientist**: Data science is an inter-disciplinary field that uses scientific methods, processes, algorithms and systems to extract knowledge and insights from many structural and unstructured data. Data science is related to data mining, machine learning and big data.

* **Software Engineer**: Software engineering is the systematic application of engineering approaches to the development of software. Software engineering is a computing discipline.

* **Data Analyst**: The Data Analyst is the professional whose focus of analysis and problem solving relates to data, types of data, and relationships among data elements within a business system or IT system.

* **Research Scientist**: Research scientists are responsible for designing, undertaking and analysing information from controlled laboratory-based investigations, experiments and trials.

* **Statistician**: A statistician is a person who works with theoretical or applied statistics. The profession exists in both the private and public sectors. statisticians are concerned with the collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation of quantitative information

* **Product/Project Manager**: Products/Project Manager is responsible for the project coordination, planning and research required for the identification and introduction of new products and busines opportunities.

* **Machine Learning Engineer**: Machine learning engineers sit at the intersection of software engineering and data science. They leverage big data tools and programming frameworks to ensure that the raw data gathered from data pipelines are redefined as data science models that are ready to scale as needed.

* **Business Analyst**: Business analyst help guide businesses in improving processes, products, services and software through data analysis. These agile workers straddle the line between IT and the business to help bridge the gap and improve efficiency. 

* **DBA/Database Engineer**: Database engineers create and maintain databases and database programs. Most companies that digitally store large amounts of information hire database engineers to design and maintain their database systems.

* **Data Engineer**: A data engineer is a worker whose primary job responsibilities involve preparing data for analytical or operational uses. The specific tasks handled by data engineers can vary from organization to organization but typically include building data pipelines to pull together information from different source systems; integrating, consolidating and cleansing data.

One of the most important areas of Data Science is called **Data Visualization**.


In a nutshell, **Data Visualization** is the presentation of information in an image or graphic format. It allows decision makers to see analysis results visually, so they can understand difficult concepts or identify new patterns. 

As you will see in your career, you will learn and use many Data Visualization concepts. Therefore, we will show below the tools most used by Data Scientists.
